main event: An unidentified aerial object was observed in the Biloxi, Mississippi area on 18 November 1949 by multiple reliable guards at the Biloxi Veterans Hospital, with the object resembling a cigar in shape and exhibiting unusual flight characteristics.
interesting points: The object was estimated to be approximately 200 feet in length with a corresponding diameter to that of a cigar of that size.
It was observed to be traveling from west to east at a speed of approximately 50 miles per hour, maintaining a steady flight path with no change in altitude.
No sound or exhaust trail was observed, and it disappeared behind the tree line surrounding the hospital.
Witnesses were verified as reliable by the Executive Officer of the hospital.
Local weather conditions at Keesler AFB Weather Station indicated clear visibility and typically northeast winds.
No photographs were present in the report.
Commercial, private, and military flight schedules in the vicinity at the time of the sighting were unknown.
There were no releases of testing devices recorded in the vicinity by Ordnance, Navy, Air Force, Army, or Weather Units.
The object was observed through teletype sequences of local weather conditions and a winds aloft report from the Keesler Weather Station.
sighted object: Unidentified aerial object resembling a cigar in shape
witnesses: Reliable guards at the Biloxi Veterans Hospital as verified by the Executive Officer
photographs: No photographs were present in the report
